docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: Subdivision 3 Appeal Books and other supporting documentation [rr 51.24–51.33]

heading.title: Subdivision 3 Appeal Books and other supporting documentation [rr 51.24–51.33]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: Subdivision 3 Appeal Books and other supporting documentation [rr 51.24–51.33]

leg:heading.title: Appeal Books and other supporting documentation [rr 51.24–51.33]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.24] r 51.24 Registrar to collect certain papers when notice of appeal filed (cf SCR Part 51, rules 30 and 30A)

leg:heading.title: Registrar to collect certain papers when notice of appeal filed (cf SCR Part 51, rules 30 and 30A)

p.text: On the filing of a notice of appeal, the Registrar:
may obtain from the Reporting Services Branch the original of the transcript (if any) of the proceedings in the court below, and
must obtain from the proper officer of the court below:
the exhibits, and
the list of exhibits and certificate under rule 51.43 , and
all other relevant documents before the court below, together with a list, certified by the proper officer of the court below, and
the reasons for judgment (if any) or the summing up (if any) in the court below certified by or on behalf of the court below.
Unless the Appeal Book is prepared by the Registrar, the Registrar must allow the party required to prepare the Appeal Book to have custody of the documents necessary to prepare it.

The party having custody of documents pursuant to subrule (2) must return them intact to the Registrar on completion of the Red Book, at which time the Registrar must make them available to other interested parties for the purpose of preparing written submissions and chronologies.
Documents are to be made available to more than one party in accordance with an agreed schedule of access or as determined by the Registrar.
Subject to this rule, the Registrar must retain the documents obtained under subrule (1) until disposal of the appeal and then return them to the officers or persons from whom they were obtained.
Legislation cited in [51.24.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Appeal proceedings are conducted on the basis of the evidence adduced in the course of the first instance hearing — unless there is a successful application for leave to adduce further evidence.

The rules contain specific provisions prescribing the manner and timing in which the pleadings and evidence are to be assembled for the purposes of the appeal proceedings. The material must be assembled in “Appeal Books”. The required form and contents of the Appeal Books is designed to facilitate the efficient conduct of appeals and to assist the Court of Appeal. That assistance is best provided if parties pay careful attention to, and comply with, the detailed provisions of the rules in preparing the Appeal Books. In particular, preparation of the Appeal Books should not be treated as a merely mechanical administrative exercise and wholly delegated to persons unfamiliar with either the particular proceedings or the rules. Everyone involved in the preparation of the Appeal Books should understand the particular rule requirements and the importance of compliance with them. As to the possibility of costs sanctions for non-compliance, see [51.29.5] . The detailed prescriptions relating to the content and preparation of these books are contained in UCPR rr 51.25–51.33 . Those requirements can be summarised as follows.

row.entry: summons, judgment, summary of argument,draft notice of appeal
within 6 weeks of Notice of Appeal

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.25] r 51.25 Preparation of Appeal Book (cf SCR Part 51, rule 31)

leg:heading.title: Preparation of Appeal Book (cf SCR Part 51, rule 31)

p.text: Unless the Court directs otherwise, the Appeal Book must be prepared by the appellant in accordance with this rule.
It must be divided into sections in accordance with rule 51.26 .
The pages in each section must be numbered consecutively and, if a section exceeds 300 pages, it must be bound in separate volumes of not more than 250 pages.
The contents must be printed, or otherwise reproduced, with a 5 millimetre margin on the right hand side of each page and evenly marked in the margin with the letters “A” to “Z”.
[subr (4) am Amendment 21 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[5], effective 7 March 2008]
Each section must have a title page setting out the full and correct title of the proceedings, including the following:
title of the court below,
names of the solicitors for each party,
the address for service for each party,
the telephone, email address, facsimile and reference number of each party.
[subr (5) am Amendment 21 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[6], effective 7 March 2008]

The index must follow, showing the page number where each document is reproduced and, in the case of exhibits, the page of the Black or Combined Book containing the transcript where the exhibit was marked.
If a section is bound in 2 or more volumes, each volume must contain an index of the entire section, unless otherwise directed by the Court.
This Subdivision prevails over rule 4.3 to the extent of any inconsistency.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.26] r 51.26 Division of Appeal Book (cf SCR Part 51, rules 32 and 32A)

leg:heading.title: Division of Appeal Book (cf SCR Part 51, rules 32 and 32A)

p.text: Subject to subrule (2), the Appeal Book must be divided into the following 4 sections:
the formal section in a red cover (the Red Book),
the transcript section in a black or grey cover (the Black Book),
the document section in a blue cover (the Blue Book),
the submissions and chronology section in an orange cover (the Orange Book).
If the total number of pages in the Black and Blue Books would not exceed 300, they may be combined in one book with a black or grey cover (the Combined Book).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.27] r 51.27 Contents of Red Book (cf SCR Part 51, rule 33)

leg:heading.title: Contents of Red Book (cf SCR Part 51, rule 33)

p.text: The Red Book must contain:
an index, and
the process and pleadings of every party as last amended and any relevant earlier versions, and
a sealed or certified copy of the judgment or order, and
the reasons for judgment or summing up below, and
the notice of appeal and any notice of cross-appeal and, if available, the notice of contention, and
the transcript of the application for leave to appeal or to cross-appeal, if applicable, and
any affidavit filed pursuant to rule 51.22 , and
any notice of appearance under rule 6.11(1) .
The pages of the Red Book must be one-sided (that is, with writing on one side of the page).
[r 51.27 am Amendment 21 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[7], effective 7 March 2008]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.28] r 51.28 Contents of Black Book (cf SCR Part 51, rule 34)

leg:heading.title: Contents of Black Book (cf SCR Part 51, rule 34)

p.text: Subject to subrules (2) and (3), the Black Book must contain:
an index, and
the evidence of each witness, and
cross-examination, and
re-examination, and
written submissions, and
addresses (if available), and
the transcript of the hearing including, where the trial is with a jury, the return of the jury’s verdict, and
any written questions submitted to the jury.
The transcript, written submissions and addresses are to be included in the Black Book only to the extent that they are necessary for the hearing and determination of the proceedings.
If there is no such transcript:
a Black Book does not have to be prepared, and
a statement to the effect that a Black Book has not been prepared because there is no transcript is to be included in the Orange Book.
The pages of the Black Book must be two-sided (that is, with writing on both sides of the page).
[subr (4) insrt Amendment 21 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[8], effective 7 March 2008]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.29] r 51.29 Contents of Blue Book (cf SCR Part 51, rule 35)

leg:heading.title: Contents of Blue Book (cf SCR Part 51, rule 35)

p.text: Subject to subrule (5), the Blue Book must contain:
an index, and
all documents before the court below (other than those in the Red and Black Books) relevant and necessary for the hearing and determination of the proceedings.
An index of the Blue Book must:
in the case of affidavits or statements:
include reference to each annexure including the first page at which it appears in the book, and
indicate which parts of affidavits, statements and annexures were rejected, not read, or admitted for a limited purpose, and
in the case of exhibits:
give the date of each exhibit and indicate whether it is reproduced in the Appeal Book and the page on which it is located, and
refer to the exhibits in the order they have been lettered or numbered as exhibits, and
refer to the pages of the Black Book where the exhibits were marked, and
where an exhibit consists of a bundle of documents — list each document that forms part of the exhibit and the page on which it is located.

If the text of affidavits or statements is reproduced, pages or annexures not admitted in evidence must be excluded or marked to indicate their evidentiary status (as rejected, not read, or admitted for a limited purpose) unless they are relevant to a ground of appeal, cross-appeal or contention.
The following provisions apply to exhibits:

exhibits must be arranged, not in the order in which they have been lettered or numbered as exhibits, but in chronological order according to their dates or, in the case of manifestly or admittedly misdated documents, their known date,

if a document is undated, it must be placed in the sequence contended for by the appellant, but the appellant must inform the respondent of the proposed position and the respondent may require that a “date or order disputed” be inserted in the index against the document,

if the exhibits include correspondence that should be read consecutively and not interspersed among other documents, the correspondence must be arranged in chronological order and given a position together, at a convenient place, in relation to the other exhibits,
if the exhibits include medical reports:
where provided by only one doctor — they must be arranged in chronological order and given a position together, at a convenient place, in relation to the other exhibits, and

where provided by more than one doctor — they must be grouped together by doctor in alphabetical order by surname at a convenient place in relation to the other exhibits and chronologically for each doctor,
any photographs and plans must be included unless irrelevant to the grounds of appeal, cross-appeal or contention, and if necessary reduced in size,
interrogatories, answers and affidavits of documents must only be included to the extent they were put in evidence.
If there are no such documents, a Blue Book does not have to be prepared.
The pages of the Blue Book must be two-sided (that is, with writing on both sides of the page).
[subr (6) insrt Amendment 21 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[9], effective 7 March 2008]

level.toc-caption: [51.29.5] Blue Book — index, order and relevance

heading.title: Blue Book — index, order and relevance

p.text: The Blue Book should be confined to the admissible relevant evidence. That evidence should be identified and presented in a way that permits ready understanding of the relevant matters. Documents should be specifically indexed. (An index entry that merely describes a category of documents — for example, “Plaintiff’s Medical Reports” — does not comply with the rule.) Generally, documents should be indexed and arranged in chronological order. However, it may be appropriate, in some circumstances, to present related documents, including a sequence of reports or correspondence, in a separate, distinctly identified, section of the appeal book.

The judges of the Court of Appeal have periodically emphasised the practical importance of substantial compliance with the present rule, and the potential availability of costs sanctions where a failure to comply occasions costs or delay: see The Nominal Defendant v Kostic [2007] NSWCA 14; BC200700661 at [81] (no proper index of significant number of medical reports, significantly hampered examination — order made that the costs of the blue book not recoverable from the appellant or the respondent ie, to be paid by appellant’s solicitors); Whalen v Kogarah Municipal Council [2007] NSWCA 5; BC200700445 at [44] (papers not paginated and no index included — inadvertence by appellant’s solicitors — costs of blue book excluded from costs order — not recoverable from either appellant or respondent, borne by appellant’s solicitors).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.30] r 51.30 Contents of Orange Book (cf SCR Part 51, rule 35A)

leg:heading.title: Contents of Orange Book (cf SCR Part 51, rule 35A)

p.text: The Orange Book must contain:
the consolidated index or, if applicable, an index of its contents, and
the appellant’s submissions and chronology in their final form with references that comply with rule 51.36(1)(b) , and
the submissions and chronologies served on the appellant by other parties in their final form, and
any amended notice of appeal, notice of cross-appeal or notice of contention, in their final form, and
any statement required by rule 51.28(3)(b) .
The pages of the Orange Book must be one-sided (that is, with writing on one side of the page).
[subr (2) insrt Amendment 21 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[10], effective 7 March 2008]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.31] r 51.31 Disputes as to contents of Appeal Book (cf SCR Part 51, rule 36)

leg:heading.title: Disputes as to contents of Appeal Book (cf SCR Part 51, rule 36)

p.text: A party who:
objects to the inclusion of material in the Appeal Book on the ground that it is unnecessary or irrelevant, or
asserts that further material should be included,
must, within 7 days of service of the relevant part of the Appeal Book on the party, serve a written notice containing the party’s objection or assertion on any other interested party.
The party preparing the Appeal Books may, with the consent of all other parties (other than a submitting party) add pages to, or delete pages from, the Appeal Book:
at any time at least 14 days before the hearing of the appeal, or
after that time, with the leave of the Court.
If an Appeal Book is amended in accordance with subrule (2), the index to the relevant section and the consolidated index are to be amended accordingly.

A party who asserts that additional material should be included in the Appeal Book must, unless all other parties who have not submitted have agreed to the inclusion, lodge 4 copies of the additional material and serve 3 copies at least 7 days before the hearing on each other interested party.
The additional material referred to in subrule (4) must be indexed and, if it consists of more than 30 pages, bound as a supplementary Black Book or Blue Book (as the case requires).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.32] r 51.32 Filing, lodgment and service of sections of Appeal Book (cf SCR Part 51, rules 37 and 37AA)

leg:heading.title: Filing, lodgment and service of sections of Appeal Book (cf SCR Part 51, rules 37 and 37AA)

p.text: The appellant must:
within 6 weeks of filing the notice of appeal:
file a copy of the Red Book, and
serve 3 copies on each other interested party, and
not less than 4 weeks before the date fixed for hearing of the appeal, lodge a further 3 copies of the Red Book with the Registrar.

The appellant must, not less than 10 weeks before the date fixed for the hearing of the appeal, serve on each interested party 3 copies of each of the Blue and Black Books or, where relevant, the Combined Book.
The appellant must, not less than 4 weeks before the date fixed for the hearing of the appeal:
file 4 copies of:
each of the Black and Blue Books or, if relevant, the Combined Book, and
the Orange Book, and
serve on each interested party 3 copies of the Orange Book.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.33] r 51.33 Overriding obligation to file Orange Book (cf SCR Part 51, rule 37A)

leg:heading.title: Overriding obligation to file Orange Book (cf SCR Part 51, rule 37A)

p.text: The appellant must ensure that the Orange Book is filed in accordance with rule 51.32 (3) and, where necessary, must arrange to have the timetable prescribed by this Part varied by consent, or by direction of the Court, in order to achieve this overriding obligation.
All other parties must cooperate with the appellant to enable the appellant to comply with subrule (1).
If any default by another party prevents, or is likely to prevent, compliance with subrule (1), the appellant must apply promptly for a directions hearing.
